# PCR Plugin

## Overview

This is a Visual Basic Excel plugin that simulates PCR products given a set of sequences of primers and templates. The simulator assumes that the template is double-stranded/circular, and is capable to doing IPCRs. 

The simulator finds the best annealing sites inn the template for the 3' ends of the oligos and calculates the final product sequence. It throws an exceptioni if the annealling ~20bp of an oligo contains degeneracy codes. However, the simulator does allow for degeneracy codes in other parts of the sequences. 


## Installation
To use this Excel Add-in:
1. Clone the repository: `git clone https://github.com/guor8lei/pcr-plugin.git`
2. Open up an empty Excel workbook.
3. Install the `SyntheticBiologyPlugin.xlam` Add-In. See [here](https://www.contextures.com/exceladdins.html#install) for instructions on how to do this in Office for Windows, and [here](https://www.excelcampus.com/install-excel-add-in-mac-2011/) for instructions on how to do this in Office for Mac.
4. Alternatively, you can create a new Add-In and import the individual modules. There are 4 PCR simulator modules you can import: `PCRSimulatorV1.bas`,`PCRSimulatorV2.bas`, `PCRSimulatorV3.bas`, and `PCRSimulatorV4.bas`. In addition, there are 2 helper modules to import: `CollectionUtil.bas` (contains all helper functions for managing lists and sets in Excel VBA) and  `SeqUtil.bas` (contains all helper functions for managing and manipulating DNA sequences).

## Usage
This Add-In contains 3 separate functions for simulating PCR products, as well as a variety of functions useful for manipulating DNA sequences:

- `=PCR(primer1, primer2, template?)` - Predicts PCR product based on a combination of `PCRSimulatorV2` and `PCRSimulatorV4`
- `=PCR_V1(primer1, primer2, template)` - Predicts PCR product based on `PCRSimulatorV1` (see Approaches below)
- `=PCR_V2(primer1, primer2, template)` - Predicts PCR product based on `PCRSimulatorV2` (see Approaches below)
- `=PCR_V3(primer1, primer2, template)` - Predicts PCR product based on `PCRSimulatorV3` (see Approaches below)
- `=PCR_V4(primer1, primer2, template)` - Predicts PCR product based on `PCRSimulatorV4` (see Approaches below)
- `=PCR_V3(primer1, primer2, "")` - Predicts PCR product without template based on `PCRSimulatorV3` (see Approaches below)
- `=PCR_V4(primer1, primer2, "")` - Predicts PCR product without template based on `PCRSimulatorV4` (see Approaches below)
- `=IsValidDNA(str)` - Checks if input is a valid DNA sequence (degenerate bases allowed)
- `=ReverseComplement(forwardRead)` - Returns reverse complement of DNA sequence
- `=EditDistance(s1, s2)` - Compute edit distance between two Strings using the Smith-Waterman Algorithm, does not count degenerate base pairs
- `=RotateStringLeftBy(inputStr, d)` - Rotates string left (anti-clockwise) by d elements
- `=RotateString(inputStr, offset)` - Rotates string to desired offset
- `=IsDegenerateDna(str)` - Check if input contains one or more degenerate base pair 
- `=CountDegenerateBases(str)` - Returns the number of degenerate base pairs in the input sequence

For examples of how the three simulators perform on different possible inputs, see `Examples.xlsx`. Below is the screenshot of it:
![screenshot here](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/guor8lei/pcr-plugin/master/img/examples_screenshot.png)

At the bottom of this README, I've also put a table containing the outputs of each PCR simulator.

## Approaches
This repository contains 4 separate PCR simulators, each with its own approach. These 4 simulators' approaches, specifically `PCRSimulatorV2` and `PCRSimulatorV4`, were combined to create the current working version of `PCRSimulator`.

#### `PCRSimulatorV1`
I wrote `PCRSimulatorV1` as my first initial attempt to simulate PCR products. I essentially based the approach on intuitively what I did in ApE whenever I wanted to predict the PCR product. Here is the general approach this simulator takes:
- Validate input primers and template as valid DNA sequences.
- Duplicate template to simulate a circulate template.
- Find best annealing sites for template by starting with the longest possible anneal site (the entire length of the primer) and scanning for exact matches in the template, iteratively decreasing the anneal site until an exact match is found.
- Find best annealing sites for reverse template with the same approach.
- Choose best annealing sites by comparing the length of the matches between the template and the reverse template.
- Construct the flanking region based on the indexes of the annealing sites.
- Construct the PCR product.

Overall, this approached worked well with the majority of the inputs, including regular PCRs, PCR with mutagenic oligos, IPCRs, PCRs with reverse complemented templates, and PCRs where the template needed to be rotated for the oligos to anneal. However, it was too restrictive in that the annealing regions had to be exact matches. It also required exactly one template. In addition, it did not simulate PCR accurately biologically, as annealing regions are usually built up from 6 base pair matches. 

#### `PCRSimulatorV2`
`PCRSimulatorV2` was my second attempt at simulating PCR products. I took a more biologically-based approach with this simulator. The code is based on Prof. Anderson's `PCRSimulator` class in `ConstructionFileSimulator`. Here is the general approach this simulator takes:
- Validate input primers and template as valid DNA sequences.
- Duplicate template to simulate a circulate template.
- Find all 6bp matches between the first primer and the template. Choose the best annealing region for the first primer that minimizes the edit distance required for an exact match in the next 25bp next to each 6bp region.
- Rotate the template accordingly so that it starts with the best annealing region for the first primer.
- Repeat the process for the second primer, this time without rotating the template.
- Construct the flanking region based on the indexes of the annealing sites.
- Construct the PCR product.

Overall, this approached worked just as well as `PCRSimulatorV1`; it predicted the correct products for everything listed above. In addition, it was much more flexible by minimizing edit distance as opposed to requiring an exact match. However, it still required a single template, and was not truly simulating the full dissocation and annealing process of PCR with more than 3 sequences.

#### `PCRSimulatorV3`
`PCRSimulatorV3` takes a similar approach to simulating PCR products as `PCRSimulatorV2`, but it is much more flexible in allowing multiple fragments by fully simulating the dissocation and annealing process. The code is based on Prof. Anderson's `NewPCRSimulator` class in `ConstructionFileSimulator`. 

The simulator performs accurately for regular PCRs, PCRs with reverse complemented templates, PCRs where the template needed to be rotated for the oligos to anneal, and PCRs with 2 oligos and no template. However, similar to `NewPCRSimulator`, it did not perform accurately with PCR with mutagenic oligos or IPCRs. Further investigation is needed to resolve these bugs. 

Another disadvantage of this simulator is that it runs much slower than the previous two simulators. The main reason for this may be due to the lack of a Set data structure in Excel VBA that is supported both in Windows and Mac, so a list was used as a replacement.

#### `PCRSimulatorV4`
`PCRSimulatorV4` is extremely similar to `PCRSimulatorV3` but it insteads incorporates a breaker variable to prevent infinite loops when simulating annealing and disassociation. In addition, instead of handling circular templates by just concatenating two copies of the template together, this simulator insteads strategically rotates the template so that the full oligo doesn't span across the beginning and the end anymore. The code is based on Prof. Anderson's merged `PCRSimulator` class in `ConstructionFileSimulator`. 

The simulator performs accurately for regular PCRs, PCRs with reverse complemented templates, PCRs where the template needed to be rotated for the oligos to anneal, IPCRs, and PCRs with 2 oligos and no template. 

However, the simualtor still runs slow due to the Excel VBA data structure limitations.

## Testing

The full test cases are shown in `Examples.xlsx`. Overall, the PCR simulator correctly predicts the majority of products, but is unable to handle experiments involving multiple templates (SOEing and PCA). In addition, it also sometimes predicts a product that should not be expected.

| Test Description                                                        | Predicted Correct Product? |
|-------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------|
| PCRSimulatorTest1                                                       |                            |
| Simple   PCR                                                            | TRUE                       |
| 5' Tails                                                                | TRUE                       |
| Long 5'   Tails on Linear Template                                      | TRUE                       |
| Mutagenic   Oligos on Lienar template                                   | TRUE                       |
| Circular   Template Over Origin                                         | TRUE                       |
| Circular   Template Over Origin, Long 5' Tails (CRISPR)                 | TRUE                       |
| Circular   Template Over Origin, Long 5' Tails, Flipped Oligos (CRISPR) | TRUE                       |
| Klenow   Extension, No Template                                         | TRUE                       |
| Degenerate   Oligos                                                     | FALSE                      |
| Not Supported/Tested: SOEing,   PCA (multiple templates)                |                            |
|                                                                         |                            |
| PCRSimulatorTest2                                                       |                            |
|        testSimplePCR                                                    | TRUE                       |
|        testOrdinaryPCR                                                  | TRUE                       |
|        testDistinguishes                                                | TRUE                       |
|        testRespectsSixBases                                             | TRUE                       |
|        testBubble                                                       | TRUE                       |
|        testCircular                                                     | TRUE                       |
|        testIndependent                                                  | TRUE                       |
|        testRevcomp                                                      | FALSE                      |
|        testReversed                                                     | TRUE                       |
|        testSixBP                                                        | TRUE                       |
|        testIllegalArgument                                              | TRUE                       |

## Future

Future improvements should be focused on fixing the bugs in the `PCRSimulator` and expanding its functionality to allow for multiple templates. Based on the testing results, there are still certain cases where the PCR simulator fails to predict the correct products.
